Matt,
Easy question first -- the usual translation of tekkotsu is "iron bones."  Don't think of a dry skeleton here, it's more like the look of your knuckle bones and skin when you make a fist.

I'm no longer so sure about the idea of tsuba surfaces being remelted.  It's mentioned in various sources and seems like a plausible process.  It looks a lot like the melted glaze on a piece of ceramic.  But when I talk about this with smiths they do not believe that it is possible.  They say that the surface would be burned rather than melted.  I have followed up with questions about fluxes and atmospheres that might make it possible, but haven't gotten anywhere.  However, I also haven't gotten anywhere when I ask how they think that those "melted" surfaces were really produced.  I'm still looking for answers on this one.

There are other groups that made these "melted" yakite finishes.  

Also, there are a number of other explanations for the formation of tekkotsu including inhomogeneities in carbon content and subsequent wear and rusting.  I think that there is some truth in all of them.  I had a chance to glance at the link that Rich provided and I think that it is good stuff.  Busy day today, so a quick answer.

Jim


  Hi Jim, on the website you write: ' These tsuba appear to have been
  finished by slightly melting the surface after forging and shaping. This
  brings out tekkotsu from the high carbon inclusions in the iron'

  Was this done at any other schools or is this peculiar to Kanayama? 

  Als if you had to translate 'tekkotsu' in English what would it be? I
  know what it is (at least I think I do) but I can't for the life of me
  think what you would call it in English. 

  Matt
